utterance.content: Oh my God. Sadie.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Call 911! Call 911!

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: I’m serious, okay? Don’t get cocky. This is the first time you’ll be testifying in court and it can get … nerve racking.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I’ll be fine. Especially since word on the street is the defense lawyer is a total hack.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Oh yeah? Who is it?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Stan Novak?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Short attention span Stan? That guy gets lost in his own cross examinations. Yeah, you will be fine.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Too bad you won’t be there to see me in action.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: No, but I will.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Is that wise? I mean, publicly aren’t we still supposed to be separated?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: This is the Sadie Beakman murder trial we’re talking about. Her reporting from Iraq shaped the way many Americans saw the war. Plus it gave her the profile to launch her own news website. And as captain of the precinct that closed her murder case it would odd if I didn’t show.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: But then we should come up with a secret signal. A little thing just between the two of us that says “I love you”.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You know, I think that would be a little – – do you need a tissue?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: No, this is my – that’s the secret “I love you” signal. You like it?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Rubbing your nose?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Yeah, that’s really romantic. Anyway, I’ve gotta go and meet Vikram? Yes, I love you, too.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: VIKRAM SINGH
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Where are we on surveilling Caleb Brown and connecting him to LokSat?

utterance.speaker: VIKRAM
utterance.content: Exactly where we were last week. And the week before that. And the week before that.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: So … nowhere?

utterance.speaker: VIKRAM
utterance.content: Our target at the public defender’s office is like a super villain. No weaknesses.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Oh, come on. That’s not possible.

utterance.speaker: VIKRAM
utterance.content: You sure about that? Because Cece and I have tried every possible –

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Wait, what? Who’s Cece?

utterance.speaker: VIKRAM
utterance.content: No one.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Did you give your computer a girl’s name?

utterance.speaker: VIKRAM
utterance.content: You don’t know my life.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Huh. I’ve never been happier about that until this moment. Look, I am tired of lying to everyone. I want my life back. And given your new relationship with your computer it’s time you get yours back, too. So let’s figure this out. What is Caleb Brown’s weakness?

utterance.speaker: MARCUS WELLER
utterance.content: This is going to be the easiest case I have ever tried.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: How can you be so sure?

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: The defendant has a history of arrest for robbing high-end houses while working as a cater waiter. Sadie Beakman caught her in the act and the defendant killed her in order to get away.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Isn’t that all circumstantial?

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: Yes, which is why it’s a good thing that I have you, an eyewitness. The defendant really should have taken that plea deal I offered.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yeah. Why didn’t she? What do you think their defense is going to be?

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: Don’t concern yourself with that. No matter how he tries to spin the facts you stick with what you saw.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Nina O’Keefe killed Sadie Beakman.

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: The victim’s family.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Oh, yes. I remember. Hi. Nice to see you again. Sorry it’s under such terrible circumstances.

utterance.speaker: ANNIE BEAKMAN
utterance.content: Yeah, us too.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So how are you holding up?

utterance.speaker: LLOYD BEAKMAN
utterance.content: Some good days, more bad. We can’t seem to get over it. You know, my wife spent two years embedded with troops in Iraq and not a scratch. And then at a party in Manhattan. It doesn’t make sense.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Well, we’re going to get her justice.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Marcus, hey.

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: Glad you could make it, Captain.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: So, um, what is this I hear about you asking Lanie out?

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: No, no, no. You got that wrong. Lanie asked me out.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Really? That’s what I –

utterance.speaker: CALEB BROWN
utterance.content: Nina. My name is Caleb Brown from the public defender’s office. I’ll be representing you today.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: What is Caleb Brown doing here?

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: That’s a good question.

utterance.speaker: BAILIFF
utterance.content: All rise. This court is now in session, the Honorable Judge Gloria Wollcott presiding.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE GLORIA WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: Be seated. Well, well, well, Mr. Caleb Brown. As lovely as it is to see you in my courtroom, where is Mr. Novak?

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: Your Honor, Mr. Novak’s wife went into premature labor last night.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: Oh no.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: The baby’s fine, as is the mother. But obviously Mr. Novak is unavailable so the public defender’s office asked me to take over.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: And you’re up to speed on the case?

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: Yes, your Honor. Plus, I did a little work of my own this morning.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: Any objections, Mr. Weller?

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: None, your Honor.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: Then let’s proceed, shall we? Bailiff, bring in the jury.

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: The people call Roger Masters, your Honor.

utterance.speaker: ROGER MASTERS
utterance.content: Sadie was kind. Thoughtful. She was generous. I would know, we were friends for over twenty years. I was her cameraman back when she was still a news correspondent, before she started her website.

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: Thank you, Mr. Masters. No further questions.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: So the murder took place at your townhouse, is that correct?

utterance.speaker: MASTERS
utterance.content: I’m afraid so. My wife and I hosted the cocktail party where your client killed Sadie.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: Did you see my client kill her?

utterance.speaker: MASTERS
utterance.content: No. No, I did not.

utterance.speaker: LANIE PARISH
utterance.content: The fireplace poker punctured the ribcage and nicked Mrs. Beakman’s aorta causing massive blood loss and her eventual death.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: Did Mrs. Beakman die immediately?

utterance.speaker: LANIE
utterance.content: It would have taken five to ten minutes for her to succumb to her wounds.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: Dr. Parish, would Mrs. Beakman have been in much pain?

utterance.speaker: LANIE
utterance.content: Yes. Excruciating pain.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: No further questions your Honor.

utterance.speaker: JAVIER ESPOSITO
utterance.content: The defendant was on the run until me and my partner –

utterance.speaker: KEVIN RYAN
utterance.content: - until my partner and I caught up with her at Grand Central terminal.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: And did my client confess?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: No. She didn’t make a statement. The only thing she said was –

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: - she said was that she wanted to speak with a lawyer.

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: The people call Richard Castle.

utterance.speaker: BAILIFF
utterance.content: Raise your right hand.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Oh, sorry. This right hand.

utterance.speaker: BAILIFF
utterance.content: Do you swear to tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I do.

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: Mr. Castle, what is it that you do for a living?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I’m a murder mystery novelist.

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: Have you held any other jobs?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yes, six years as a civilian investigator working with the NYPD. Homicides for the Twelfth Precinct.

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: So you’re a bit of an expert when it comes to solving murders.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yes, and I use that expertise to lend authenticity to my novels.

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: Now, what brought you to the home of Roger and Joanna Masters on the evening of September 14th, five months ago?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Joanna Masters won a charity auction to have me come to her home and do a private reading of Driving Heat, my latest novel, due to come out the following day.

utterance.speaker: JOANNA MASTERS
utterance.content: Oh, my! Richard Castle! In my home!

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: It is a pleasure to meet you.

utterance.speaker: JOANNA
utterance.content: Oh, I just adore your books. Nikki Heat is like my role model. I love her!

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Me too. You are too kind.

utterance.speaker: JOANNA
utterance.content: And you are too cute.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Keep talking.

utterance.speaker: JOANNA
utterance.content: Please, come in. Come in.

utterance.speaker: JOANNA
utterance.content: I’d like you to meet my husband, Roger.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Richard. Nice to meet you.

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: Welcome.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: JOANNA
utterance.content: And, uh, these are the Beakmans. This is Sadie.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: That’s when I met Sadie.

utterance.speaker: SADIE BEAKMAN
utterance.content: Nice to meet you.

utterance.speaker: JOANNA
utterance.content: Lloyd. And their lovely daughter, Annie.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Nice to meet you.

utterance.speaker: ANNIE
utterance.content: Nice to meet you.

utterance.speaker: JOANNA
utterance.content: Now I’m sure you recognize Sadie from her Iraq war news reports, but she also owns and operates BeakmanReport.com.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: After meeting the soon-to-be victim I met the soon-to-be killer.

utterance.speaker: NINA
utterance.content: Champagne?

utterance.content: Thank you so much for being here. Thank you for having me. Sorry about the small poster, I ran out of the big ones.

utterance.content: Driving Heat. Written by this guy.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: “The last thing Nikki Heat expected when she received her promotion to Captain of the NYPD was …”

utterance.content: After the reading I needed to use the restroom.

utterance.content: So I went to use the facilities upstairs.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Stop!

utterance.content: That’s when I saw the defendant kill Sadie Beakman.

utterance.content: Let the record reflect the witness has identified the defendant, Nina O’Keefe, as the woman in question. No further questions, your Honor.

utterance.content: Oh, no. It was definitely her.

utterance.content: And you remember the events of the evening clearly. Because I know you have a history of memory loss.

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: Objection, your Honor.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: It goes to credibility.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: I’ll allow it.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: Mr. Castle, is it true that on May 12th, 2014 you were abducted by parties still unknown and then returned eight weeks later.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: And you still have memory loss.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Only of those eight weeks. My memory of your client killing Mrs. Beakman is crystal clear.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: But how can you be sure?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Because I was an eyewitness.

utterance.content: Ah. So glad that you used that word. Eye witness. Now, Mr. Castle, you gave a reading of Driving Heat - - on the evening in question, the continuing adventures of Nikki Heat. Won’t you humor the court and just give us a short reading? Just the highlighted section, if you please.

utterance.content: “Nikki had seen it often, as every cop had. Otherwise reliable witnesses conflate or confuse details that seem indelible to those not caught up in the trauma of the incident.”

utterance.content: According to previous testimony, you use your expertise with the NYPD to add authenticity to your stories, is that correct?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: The defendant killed Mrs. Beakman. I know what I saw.

utterance.content: Just like you knew what you saw on February 2nd, 2015?

utterance.content: Mr. Castle, did you give a statement to a Detective Neely of Westchester PD that you were an eyewitness to the murder of Eva Whitfield and that her husband, Cole, was the killer?

utterance.content: Yes, I did, but –

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: And was Cole Whitfield the killer?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: No.

utterance.content: So you’ve been wrong before.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: That incident was a setup. What happened to Mrs. Beakman was not. I saw the defendant kill her.

utterance.content: Says the man whose own writings speak to the unreliability of eyewitnesses. A man who has given false eyewitnesses. A man who has given false eyewitness statements in the past. A man with a history of memory loss.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Marcus. Help him.

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: Don’t you think I would if I could?

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: Mr. Castle, let’s pretend that you’re a character out of one of your novels. Would Nikki Heat think that you are a reliable witness?

utterance.content: That is a ridiculous question. And yes, she would.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: I’m disappointed in you, Mr. Castle. I thought you of all people would be sympathetic to my client. Weren’t you once framed for murder?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: That – yeah. That was … 3KX. The serial killer. He had a vendetta against me. That – that was – that was different.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: What? Why is it different for you but not for my client? What makes you so special, Mr. Castle? utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: But that doesn’t mean –

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: This is not one of your stories, sir. You do not get to make up the facts as you see fit. Now, my client is fighting for her life, just as you once fought for yours against 3XK. So now, I ask you one last time, is it possible, Mr. Castle, that my client did not kill Mrs. Beakman?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yes, it’s possible.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: Yes. Yes, it is possible. Possible that you are wrong. Nothing further, your Honor.

utterance.content: Mr. Castle, you may step down.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: Mr. Castle, you may step down.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: Mr. Castle? Step down.

utterance.content: It’s nearly five o’clock. We will pick this back up in the morning. Court is in recess until 9AM.

utterance.content: Marcus, I’m so sorry. I don’t know what happened. I got torpedoed.

utterance.content: Are you okay?

utterance.content: Beckett, I just blew the entire case.

utterance.content: Well the trial’s not over yet. Right Marcus?

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: Look, I’m not going to lie to you. We’ve got a serious problem now. Castle, you’ve just given the jury reasonable doubt.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: But there’s gotta be something we can do, right?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Well we’ve got until court resumes tomorrow morning to find new evidence or another witness who can prove Nina’s guilt.

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: Yes. However, what can you possibly uncover in less than sixteen hours?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: I don’t know. But we have to try.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: How many more times do we have to go through theses case files?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: As many as it takes.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Beckett, we’ve got stacks and stacks of hay here, but no needles. I think we need a new strategy.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I can’t believe how badly I blew it up there. This is my fault, guy. I’m sorry.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Don’t do that to yourself. We’ve all been tripped up on the witness stand.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: True. Back when I was in uniform a defense attorney got my head so turned around that I testified that the defendant actually kicked my ass when I tried to arrest her.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: What’s wrong with that?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: The defendant was a seventy five year old woman in a wheelchair. I lost all credibility with the jury.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: To this day we pass the park where she feeds the birds. She snickers, turns to her nurse, and tells her the tale of how she got one over on poor old Javi.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Miss Lucinda. I will get her one day.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: But have any of you botched your testimony in a murder trial. Exactly.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Hey, Espo, that story about Miss Lucinda. So she still talks about how she made a fool out of you?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Yes. Thank you for rubbing it in, Captain Beckett.

utterance.content: Hey. Thank you.

utterance.content: For what?

utterance.content: For not giving up on me.

utterance.content: Well, you’ve never given up on me, so…

utterance.content: Castle, wait. Um … not here.

utterance.content: Oh, right. Separated. Well …

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Are you okay? Do you have allergies?

utterance.content: No, that’s the – that’s the signal. That’s the “I love you”. That’s the –

utterance.content: What do you know?

utterance.content: Okay, Bridget, what do you want?

utterance.content: Oh, what does any girl want, Detective?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: The personal satisfaction of bringing a killer to justice?

utterance.speaker: BRIDGET
utterance.content: Fifty bucks in the prison commissary every week for the next ten weeks.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Forty bucks for five weeks.

utterance.speaker: BRIDGET
utterance.content: Eight. And that’s as low as I’ll go.

utterance.content: Not her boyfriend. Wait for it.

utterance.content: Her girlfriend.

utterance.content: Yep.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: The victim and the killer were having an affair? Why’s my voice so high?

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: You see, Beckett, this is why I love the Twelfth Precinct. You guys never let me down.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: This recording gives you a new motive for murder and it’s ironclad. Nina and Sadie were having an affair, clearly they were fighting, and Nina most likely killed her in a crime of passion.

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: Okay. I will have my people try track down former employees of this bar and hopefully one of them can corroborate the affair.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Okay. And I’ll have my team touch base with Sadie’s family and friends. Maybe they can shed some light as to what was behind this little love affair.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: You see, Marcus? And you were worried.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Okay, boys. We found Nina’s coffin. Now let’s nail it shut.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: I’ll talk to Nina’s employees.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: And I’ll go talk to her friends.

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: Sadie was having an affair with that woman? That is so twisted.

utterance.speaker: JOANNA
utterance.content: Well, you never know what goes on behind closed doors.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: So you knew nothing about Sadie’s extramarital affairs?

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: She was good at keeping secrets.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Then why hire the catering company that Nina worked for?

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: Sadie’s recommendation. She went to an event that she catered, said the food was amazing.

utterance.speaker: JOANNA
utterance.content: I bet that’s how Sadie and Nina met. What do you think, Richard?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Entirely possible.

utterance.speaker: JOANNA
utterance.content: See? I told you I was a Nikki Heat fan. I even think like her, too.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: It’s uncanny.

utterance.speaker: JOANNA
utterance.content: I know.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: It’s good that you moved the basketball hoop away from the townhouse.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Oh, yeah. Those things, they’re just an invitation for burglars to break in.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Or murderers like Nina to break out.

utterance.speaker: JOANNA
utterance.content: Well we always keep the hoop there. Nina moved it.

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: Yeah, we didn’t even realize that she had until the day after the murder.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: How are you sure that it was Nina that moved it?

utterance.speaker: JOANNA
utterance.content: Well, if it wasn’t her who else could it have been?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Ryan, a moment? Excuse us. The basketball hoop being moved speaks to a premeditative act.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Yeah, but our theory for this whole thing is that it was a crime of passion. What are you thinking?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: That we don’t know the whole story. Someone else was up here before I caught Nina over Sadie.

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: Please tell me you’re joking.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: The fact the basketball hoop was moved is a significant because Nina didn’t have any reason to do it.

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: Kate, why am I back here?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Marcus, this is a legitimate concern. If Nina didn’t move the hoop, who did? And why?

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: Let’s stick with what we know. Castle say Nina kill Sadie. End of story.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I’m not actually, 100% sure about that anymore.

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: Wait. Don’t tell me you’re buying into Caleb’s ridiculous defense. Rick, you got your bell rung in court today. It happens. Caleb Brown is a hell of an attorney. Now you’ve got to let it go.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So you’re not going to investigate?

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: You saw the tape. They were having an affair. It’s a crime of passion. Nina is guilty. Plain and simple.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Don’t we have to be sure?

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: Rick. Look at me. I’m sure.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Marcus, if we could just talk –

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: Stop! This case cannot afford to have you pour any more doubt into people’s ears.

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: Listen, I know you two are separated and all, but could you please talk to him?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Mmhmm.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Castle, are you sure that Nina’s innocent?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I don’t know. But what’s worse than letting a guilty person go free?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Sending an innocent one to jail. All right. Go home. I’ll sneak by later.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA RODGERS
utterance.content: So … you don’t trust what you saw?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I don’t know that I can anymore. I just … keep running it in my head, over and over again.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: And you think Nina was just trying to help this poor woman.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Nina’s back was to me. I didn’t actually see the death blow. I – believe me, you guys. It – it really looked like she did it.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Well, I believe you. It’s just, honestly, it sounds to me like Nina killed her.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS CASTLE
utterance.content: Me too.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I have to find out for sure.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Dad, there’s no way to do that.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I know. Or is there? I’ve got it. And I’d only have to do two things: one, delay the trial so I have a chance to investigate, and two, have a one-on-one conversation with Nina.

utterance.speaker: ALEXIS
utterance.content: Uh … Nina’s lawyer will never allow it.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Which is why I’m going to have to be very clever with how I go about this.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: I take it you have a plan?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: You know I do, Mother.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Might I ask you what I do?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I’m going to get thrown in jail!

utterance.speaker: JUDGE WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: Yes?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Good morning, your Honor.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: Mr. Castle, you can’t be in here.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: And yet, here I am. Your Honor, I was made a fool of yesterday on the stand. I have a reputation to protect, so I would like a do-over.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: A do-over?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: A do-over.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: Okay, two things: one, that’s stupid. And two, your presence in my chambers is highly unethical. I could hold you in contempt of court of this.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Well I would like to see you try.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: Reggie, come in here, please. Mr. Castle, I’m aware of your friendship with the mayor, so even though you don’t deserve it I’m going to let you go. Reggie, escort him out of the building, please.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Oh. Your Honor, I see you attended law school at Hudson University. That explains why you’re so bad at your job.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: Excuse me?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yes. You see, everyone knows only criminals attend Hudson University. I myself have solved three homicides there.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: Hello?

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Gloria Wollcott, please.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: Speaking.

utterance.speaker: MARTHA
utterance.content: Yes, this is Tri-Mountain Security calling. The alarm on your Connecticut home was triggered. The officer responded and I’m afraid the report is that your residence was burglarized.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: What? Okay, I’m on my way. My house has been burglarized.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Your Honor, you know who I am and what I’m capable of doing. I can find those burglars for you.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: How?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Well, first we’ll need a listing of all the Hudson University students and alumnus in the tri-state area.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: Okay, that’s it. Contempt. Have him thrown in a holding cell.

utterance.speaker: NINA
utterance.content: Hey. My trial was supposed to begin like, five minutes ago. What’s going on?

utterance.speaker: OFFICER
utterance.content: Judge postponed your trial until tomorrow. You’ll be transported back to Rikers at the end of the day.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Hey. So what are you in for? Sorry, bad joke.

utterance.speaker: NINA
utterance.content: Don’t talk to me.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Nina, look. I know about the affair. With Sadie. The ADA knows it too. He’s going to use it to bury you.

utterance.speaker: NINA
utterance.content: Why are you telling me this?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I was there, Nina. I saw you. I saw you with my own eyes.

utterance.speaker: NINA
utterance.content: I didn’t kill Sadie! I loved her. So yeah, you were there. But you saw it wrong.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So tell me what I missed.

utterance.speaker: NINA
utterance.content: I found Sadie on the ground. Someone had already stabbed her. She was struggling to breathe, so I pulled the poker out. I was trying to help her.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So then why did you run?

utterance.speaker: NINA
utterance.content: I knew how it looked. I panicked.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Why didn’t you tell that to the police when they caught you?

utterance.speaker: NINA
utterance.content: Please. I’ve been arrested before. And I got screwed over. You know why? Because none of the cops believed me. I wasn’t going to make the same mistake twice.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Did you at least tell your lawyer?

utterance.speaker: NINA
utterance.content: Of course. I told my original public defender all about the affair. But he just said it’d come across as motive. Which, surprise, surprise. It did.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: What about the fight? The fight you had with Sadie outside the bar the night before the murder.

utterance.speaker: NINA
utterance.content: That was nothing.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Nina. Nina. I think you’re telling the truth. But I can’t help you unless you tell me the whole story.

utterance.speaker: NINA
utterance.content: The fight was about a couple things. I was sick of sneaking around. But Sadie was all paranoid because she had been caught cheating with other guys in the past.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Other guys? So you were her first –

utterance.speaker: NINA
utterance.content: Lesbian? Yes. Is that a problem?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: No, not with me. You should check my search history. But you said you were arguing about a couple of things.

utterance.speaker: NINA
utterance.content: What really pissed me off was that Sadie asked me to do something at that cocktail party.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: What did she ask you to do?

utterance.speaker: NINA
utterance.content: Bring her Roger Masters’ empty champagne glass.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Roger Masters the host? Why would she want his empty glass?

utterance.speaker: NINA
utterance.content: She wouldn’t say. And that really got me fired up because if I got caught stealing, even something as trivial as a champagne glass, I would’ve lost my job.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: But you stole it for her anyway, didn’t you?

utterance.speaker: NINA
utterance.content: At the end of the day I’d do anything for Sadie. And she knew it. She had me wrapped around her finger the moment I met her.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Walk me through it. Tell me what happened.

utterance.speaker: NINA
utterance.content: When Roger was done with his champagne I retrieved the empty glass and quietly handed it off to Sadie.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: What did she do with it?

utterance.speaker: NINA
utterance.content: Went upstairs. I followed her up like, twenty minutes later to see what was going on. That’s when I found her.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: And you told all this to your lawyer?

utterance.speaker: NINA
utterance.content: Yes. My original public defender was too overloaded with other cases. And truth be told, he thought I was guilty. He wanted me to take the ADA’s plea deal. Thank God Caleb Brown took over. At least he’s fighting for me.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Yo. How’s it hanging, jail bird?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: You already pissed off the ADA so, what, you figured why the hell not piss off the judge as well?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yeah. Can you guys get me out of here?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Already done. Bailiff called us to come get you.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I’m going to figure out what happened. I promise.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Are you out of your mind?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I didn’t do anything wrong.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You tricked a judge to postpone a trial and then you illegally questioned a defendant.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yeah, but other than that I didn’t do anything wrong.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Yo Beckett, Castle’s convinced that Nina’s innocent now.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Because what? Because Sadie wanted Roger’s glass?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I think she was after his DNA.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Roger was her cameraman for twenty years. Nina said that Sadie had had affairs with men in the past. Maybe they had had one and Sadie’s daughter was actually Roger’s.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: So uh, what, you think that Sadie cooked this whole thing up so she could get a DNA sample for a paternity test?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Only one way to find out.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: What do you want us to do, Captain?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: I –

utterance.speaker: VIKRAM
utterance.content: Beckett. Look.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Uh … go talk to Roger, see what he knows.

utterance.speaker: VIKRAM
utterance.content: What is he doing here?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: I’ll handle this. You just … be no more.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: Oh, Captain, you crossed the line. I know that you had Castle go in and interview my client –

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Counselor, Castle and I are separated. He is no longer associated with the Twelfth Precinct. So neither I nor the NYPD can be held accountable for his actions.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: So you knew nothing about it?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: That’s what I said, isn’t it?

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: I don’t believe you.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: And I don’t care.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: Typical cop.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Wait.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Look, if you repeat what I’m about to tell you, I will deny it. I have people looking into Nina’s case.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: Do you believe that she’s innocent?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: I didn’t say that. But I believe we have to be thorough. And now that the trial has been postponed we have time to investigate further.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: I appreciate that, Captain.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Counselor, Nina wasn’t your client until yesterday morning. Why are you so passionate about this case?

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: Well, for the same reason that I assume you are. Justice. This is Caleb Brown. Yes. Yeah? Yeah. Yeah, I’m on my way. So while the judge was heading up she called a neighbor who checked on her house. Turns out the house was not burglarized. Anyway, she’s ordered that the trial resume in a half an hour. So if your people are going to help prove Nina’s innocence they better hurry.

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: You again.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Hello, Roger. We need to talk.

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: Well now what?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Joanna.

utterance.speaker: JOANNA
utterance.content: Well, hello!

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Sorry for the interruption. This won’t take long. It actually can’t. Trial’s going to start again in a few minutes and we need to nail down who the real killer is before an innocent woman gets convicted.

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: What do you mean, innocent? You saw that woman kill Sadie.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: No, Roger, I only thought that I did. You see the mind is a funny thing. It doesn’t like a vacuum so it fills in the blanks. Much like when I discovered Sadie and Nina were having an affair, I automatically assumed Nina killed her in a lover’s quarrel when really, the two of them were working together to get something from you, Roger.

utterance.speaker: JOANNA
utterance.content: What is he talking about?

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: I’m sure I have no idea.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: May I?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Please.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Turns out that Sadie asked Nina to bring her a glass with your DNA on it. The question is, why?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: My turn?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Go for it.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: We think that you were having an affair with Sadie.

utterance.speaker: JOANNA
utterance.content: I knew it! All those years you were working together, your little secret conversations. You were cheating on me this whole time, weren’t you?

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: Honey, it’s not true, I swear.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: See, Sadie wanted a sample of your DNA to prove that you are the father of Sadie’s daughter.

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: Oh.

utterance.speaker: JOANNA
utterance.content: Oh, for the love of God.

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: I told you.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I don’t understand.

utterance.speaker: JOANNA
utterance.content: Roger is infertile due to a childhood illness. And Sadie knew that. Hell, the mailman probably knows it given how much Roger talks about it.

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: It was a very traumatic experience. As is this. I’d like you to leave.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Sorry Roger, no can do. Sadie wanted your glass. If not for DNA, then why?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Perhaps a fingerprint?

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Why would Sadie need his fingerprint?

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: I have no idea.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Your wife does.

utterance.speaker: JOANNA
utterance.content: Right over there. Behind the picture.

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: Joanna, how could you?

utterance.speaker: JOANNA
utterance.content: Oh, please. I’ve been dying to know what you’ve been hiding in your safe for years now, Roger. And the fact that you didn’t knock up Sadie doesn’t mean you weren’t knocking boots.

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: If you think I’m opening that without a warrant you’re crazy.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: How long would it take to get us a warrant?

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: An hour or two.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: We don’t have that kind of time. Joanna, you’re a fan of Nikki Heat.

utterance.speaker: JOANNA
utterance.content: Yeah, so?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So how would you like to have a main character named after you in my next book?

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: Joanna, don’t you dare.

utterance.speaker: JOANNA
utterance.content: How about a villain?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Deal.

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: You wouldn’t.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: What are we going to find on this tape, Roger?

utterance.speaker: SADIE
utterance.content: They said it’s here, right?

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: Yeah, but you know how they lie.

utterance.speaker: SADIE
utterance.content: Here. Got something.

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: Tell me that’s not a WMD.

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: Whoa! You know what that is?

utterance.speaker: SADIE
utterance.content: Yeah. One of the five million dollar duffel bags the CIA’s handing out all over Iraq.

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: Let’s take it.

utterance.speaker: SADIE
utterance.content: What? No.

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: Sadie, come on. It’s five million bucks. And no one’s ever going to miss it.

utterance.speaker: SADIE
utterance.content: Roger, forget about it. We’re reporters, not thieves. I’ll notify JSOP when we get back to base.

utterance.speaker: SADIE
utterance.content: All right, let’s get out of here.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: But you didn’t leave it, did you?

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: You can see on the tape that we did.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Sure, and then once you stopped recording you went back to get it.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Over a billion dollars in cash went missing in the Iraq invasion. What’s a lousy five mil? You couldn’t just leave it, could you?

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: Yet that’s exactly what I did.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Except Sadie didn’t, did she?

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: No. She didn’t. She snuck back and took it for herself and then she smuggled it to the States, tried to cut me out.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: But you had the tape and you used that to blackmail her so you could get your share.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: But Sadie didn’t like you having all that leverage. What I can’t figure out is what took Sadie so long to try to get his tape back from you.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Oh, I get it. You burned through the money that Sadie gave you originally so you needed more.

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: I am mortgaged to the hilt, okay? All my credit cards are maxed, my wife won’t stop spending. Hell, she forked over fifteen Gs to that stupid charity auction to have the great Richard Castle read a couple of chapters out of his novel.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Okay, so you went to Sadie demanding more money. She refused. And then when you caught her in your office that night trying to take what was yours –

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: You grabbed the fireplace poker and you killed her.

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: No! I didn’t even know Sadie was trying to steal the tape until you guys showed up at my house earlier.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Prove it. Where were you at the time of the murder?

utterance.speaker: ROGER
utterance.content: You promise not to tell my wife? I was in the basement getting baked with Chip Evans and Lester Davis. I lied because I promised my wife I would stop toking. It’s just – I – I’m under a lot of stress lately.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Please tell me you solved it.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Roger’s alibi checks out. We’re back to square one with zero leads. Any luck with Weller?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: He only cares about getting a conviction. From the look of the jury when they found out about Nina and Sadie’s affair he’s going to get it.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: We need to figure something out.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I have an idea.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Castle, what are you doing?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Saving an innocent woman’s life.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: Mr. Brown, your witness.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Stop the trial!

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Okay, so … now what?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I don’t know. I didn’t think this one all the way through.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Hello, you Honor. Nice to see you again.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: Hoping to make another trip to the holding cells, Mr. Castle?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: No, your Honor. Once was plenty. And my sincerest apologies for the interruption. However there has been a development in the case.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Excuse us, your Honor, but the defense has a witness to call to the stand.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: Um … your Honor, the defense would like to call Richard Castle to the stand.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: So Nina definitely didn’t do it.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: Tell me something I don’t know, like who did?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: No idea.

utterance.speaker: BAILIFF
utterance.content: Swear to tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I do. Looks like I got my do-over after all.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: Um … Mr. Castle, yesterday you testified my client was guilty of killing Mrs. Beakman. Do you still believe that’s true?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: No. Nina’s innocent.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: Okay. And when, may I ask, did you change your mind about my client?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: When I realized that Nina was a victim. A victim of bad timing, first and foremost my own.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: Bad timing, you say?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: It was my bad timing that brought me to the crime scene too late. Had I gotten there earlier I would have seen Nina finding Sadie already stabbed.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: Okay, but then my client ran. Why?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Because she knew how it looked. While we’re on the topic of bad timing, let’s not fail to mention the timing of Nina originally being paired with a public defender who didn’t care about the truth. Unlike you, sir.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: Um … well, Mr. Castle, is there anything – is there anything else you’d like to share with the court?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yes. Good people of the jury, it is frightening to think about but Nina O’Keefe is on trial today simply because I needed to use the restroom and the one downstairs – – bad timing.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: The bathroom downstairs was occupied.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Call 911! Call 911!

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I was rushing to the back of the house thinking Nina was the killer and she was getting away, but the true killer never left. The true killer was still in that bathroom, cleaning the mud from his shoes. The mud he collected trudging through the backyard.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: To and from killing Sadie.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: And Mr. Castle, did you see this man?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yeah. Talk about bad timing. He came out just in time for me to catch him.

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: Can you point to this man in the courtroom? The man who killed Sadie Beakman?

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Yes, I can. It was her husband, Lloyd Beakman.

utterance.speaker: LLYOD
utterance.content: How dare you.

utterance.speaker: ANNIE
utterance.content: No, wait. No, you and mom disappeared from the party at the same time. No, I remember because I was trying to find you guys!

utterance.speaker: JUDGE WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: All right, that’s enough! I want order!

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Apologies to the court, your Honor. Joanna Masters thought that Sadie was having an affair with her husband, Roger. But she was wrong. And so were you.

utterance.speaker: LLOYD
utterance.content: I have absolutely no idea what you’re talking about.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Sure you do. You saw your wife head up those stairs. You had your suspicious; she had cheated on you before. So you headed out to the yard. You moved the basketball hoop over so you could climb up it and get a better look.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: But Sadie caught you spying in the window, didn’t she? So you came inside and accused her of having an affair with Roger.

utterance.speaker: ANNIE
utterance.content: Dad, what did you do?

utterance.speaker: LLOYD
utterance.content: What did I do? Your mother was having an affair with – – her, of all people. And it was so funny to your mother that I assumed it was Roger that she laughed and laughed.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: So you were upstairs with Sadie.

utterance.speaker: LLOYD
utterance.content: What – what – what I meant was –

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: What happened, Lloyd? Did you lose control, is that why you killed her?

utterance.speaker: LLOYD
utterance.content: I didn’t mean to. I didn’t – mean it. I loved Sadie, but I just – I got –

utterance.speaker: BROWN
utterance.content: Mr. Beakman, my advice to you would be to stop talking and find yourself an attorney.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Mr. Beakman, you’re under arrest for murder. Come on. Hands.

utterance.speaker: WELLER
utterance.content: Your Honor, in light of these developments the people file a motion to dismiss all charges against Nina O’Keefe.

utterance.speaker: JUDGE WOLLCOTT
utterance.content: Granted. Case dismissed.

utterance.speaker: NINA
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Great job, guys. You should be proud of yourselves.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Why? We blew it.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Yeah. For five months we had an innocent woman rotting in jail.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: No. That one’s not on us. Nina’s original defense attorney did that to her. At the end of the day we’re the ones who brought her justice.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Speaking of which, I’ve gotta take back everything bad I’ve ever said about defense attorneys. That guy, Caleb Brown, he’s all right.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: Yeah, he’s a stand-up guy.

utterance.speaker: RYAN
utterance.content: We’ll see you later, Beckett.

utterance.speaker: ESPOSITO
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: All right. Good night, guys.

utterance.speaker: VIKRAM
utterance.content: Caleb’s a stand-up guy. If they only knew.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: No, they’re right. I mean, Caleb is a monster, but what we learned today is that he is a monster who is desperate to do good.

utterance.speaker: VIKRAM
utterance.content: So?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: So we were looking for his weakness? And we just found it.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Hey, celebratory champagne. Felt appropriate given the twist it played in today’s courtroom drama.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Yes, enough drama to fill a legal thriller. Maybe you should try a new genre.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Maybe I should try to make sure I never testify in court again.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: You kept an innocent woman out of jail, Rick. I’m proud of you for that.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: I couldn’t have done it without you.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: So … how is your investigation into LokSat coming along?

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: I – you know I can’t tell you about that.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: Right, right. For my own safety.

utterance.speaker: BECKETT
utterance.content: Um … but I can tell you this. I’m getting close.

utterance.speaker: CASTLE
utterance.content: That’s good. Because so am I.

utterance.speaker: THE END
utterance.content: CASTLE
